Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Current-Free Double Layers for Spacecraft Propulsion

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAPSI award supported the PI on a trip to collaborate with researchers in the Space Plasma, Power and Propulsion (SP3) group at the Australian National University. The SP3 group is developing a new type of electrostatic ion thruster, called the Helicon Double Layer Thruster (HDLT). Electrostatic ion thrusters are a highly fuel efficient means to propel a spacecraft, with the limitation that the maximum thrust they can provide is significantly less than that of a chemical based rocket. This type of thruster is ideally suited for long-term missions and satellite station keeping.  Hundreds of electrostatic ion thrusters operate continuously in space today. One critical component of these is an electron source, which is needed to neutralize emitted ions. Electron sources are often the life-limiting component in these devices. Extending thruster life allows for the possibility of longer-term missions, as well as keeping satellites in orbit longer, which could potentially save a lot of money. The HDLT seeks to overcome the limitation of electron sources through a thruster design that can simultaneously emit an equal number of electrons and ions.

 

The ion acceleration mechanism in an HDLT is a current-free double layer, which is a type of electric field that arises when a source plasma expands into a larger vacuous region. In space, the thruster would act as the source plasma, and outer space itself as the larger vacuous region.  Proof of principle experiments of the current-free double layer mechanism have been conducted in the SP3 group since 2003. However, critical questions about the basic theory of the phenomena remain, and answering some of these questions was the goal of this research. Two questions we focused on were (1) to determine the range of pressures of neutral gas in the source region that can support a current-free double layer and (2) to determine what limits the speed of ejected ions. We found that the answer to both questions lies in a detailed understanding of the electron distribution in the source region. We developed an analytic model for the electron distribution. This model predicts a range of neutral pressures that can support a current-free double layer and predicts that the speed of ejected ions is limited to a certain fraction of the electron temperature. Both expectations were shown to agree well with numerical simulations and previous experiments. The numerical simulation technique that we used was particle-in-cell. 

 

The results of this research will be important to the future development of HDLT because they describe the critical role of the electron distribution in current-free double layers formation, the range of neutral pressures that can support a double layer, and the speed of ions ejected from the thruster. Each of these is critical to determining the thrust and other performance criteria of an HDLT.

 

The results of this work have been published in the following article:

Particle-in-cell simulations of a current-free double layer, S. D. Baalrud, T. Lafleur, R. W. Boswell and C. Charles, Physics of Plasmas 18, 063502 (2011).

 

They have also been presented at the 2010 American Physical Society Division of Plasma Physics conference.
